steps.new_information: Patient presents with generalized fatigue, mild fever, abdominal pain, and nausea.
current_uncertainties: Viral gastroenteritis: common cause of nausea, abdominal pain, fever, and fatigue
Appendicitis: can present with abdominal pain, fever, and nausea—depends on pain location and progression
Acute hepatitis: may cause fatigue, abdominal pain, nausea and low-grade fever—consider if liver-specific signs or exposures present
Urinary tract infection/pyelonephritis: can cause fever, abdominal or flank pain, and systemic symptoms including nausea and fatigue.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Vital Signs

steps.new_information: Vital signs: Temperature 38.1°C, Blood Pressure 110/74 mm Hg, Heart Rate 99/min, Respiratory Rate normal.
current_uncertainties: Viral gastroenteritis: compatible with fever, nausea, generalized abdominal pain and fatigue
Acute appendicitis: early appendicitis may present with fever, nausea and abdominal pain before localization to RLQ
Acute viral hepatitis: can cause fatigue, nausea and abdominal discomfort with low-grade fever (consider exposure history)
steps.next_step_action: ASK PATIENT: Where exactly is your abdominal pain located (please point to the spot) and when did it start?

steps.new_information: Patient reports pain localized to right upper abdomen under the ribs (RUQ) that began ~3 weeks ago and started along with fatigue and nausea.
current_uncertainties: Acute cholecystitis: RUQ pain, fever, nausea fit presentation but duration is subacute and classic Murphy sign unknown
Acute cholangitis/choledocholithiasis: fever + RUQ pain raise concern for biliary obstruction/infection though jaundice not reported
Viral hepatitis: fatigue, mild fever, RUQ discomfort and nausea over weeks could indicate hepatitis (exposure, LFTs unknown)
Hepatic abscess: subacute RUQ pain with systemic symptoms is possible though typically sicker.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Abdominal exam (assess for RUQ tenderness, Murphy sign, guarding, rebound, hepatomegaly)

steps.new_information: Liver enlarged 2–3 cm below right costal margin (hepatomegaly) with RUQ tenderness; no Murphy sign, no guarding or rebound; normal inspection and auscultation.
current_uncertainties: Acute viral hepatitis: hepatomegaly, fever, fatigue, RUQ pain and nausea over weeks fits
Hepatic abscess: fever, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly possible though often higher fever and systemic toxicity
Acute cholecystitis: RUQ pain and fever possible but absent Murphy sign and hepatomegaly make it less likely
Drug-induced or alcoholic hepatitis: hepatomegaly and systemic symptoms possible depending on exposure history.
steps.next_step_action: ASK PATIENT: Have you noticed yellowing of your skin or eyes, dark urine, or pale stools?

steps.new_information: Patient reports dark (tea-colored) urine; no scleral or skin jaundice; normal-colored stools.
current_uncertainties: Acute viral hepatitis: fever, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, dark urine suggest conjugated hyperbilirubinemia from hepatocellular injury
Choledocholithiasis/biliary obstruction: RUQ pain and dark urine possible but absence of jaundice and pale stools argues against complete obstruction
Drug-induced liver injury (hepatocellular or cholestatic): can present subacutely with hepatomegaly, RUQ pain, dark urine depending on timeline and exposures
Liver abscess: subacute RUQ pain, low-grade fever and hepatomegaly possible, though typically more febrile
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Liver function tests (AST, ALT, ALP, total and direct bilirubin), CBC, and hepatitis A/B/C serologies

steps.new_information: Marked transaminitis (AST 488 U/L, ALT 798 U/L) with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (total bilirubin 3.6 mg/dL, direct 2.4 mg/dL), hepatomegaly and RUQ tenderness; CBC shows mild anemia (Hb 10.6 g/dL) and leukocytosis (11,600/mm3); Hepatitis serologies: Hep A IgG positive, HBsAg positive, anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg positive, Hep C antibody negative.
current_uncertainties: Chronic active hepatitis B with acute flare/reactivation: positive HBsAg, anti-HBc IgG and HBeAg with high transaminases and bilirubin suggesting active HBV replication
Acute (primary) hepatitis B infection: would cause high ALT/AST and bilirubin but expected anti-HBc IgM (not provided), so less likely
Drug-induced liver injury (e.g., acetaminophen or other hepatotoxins): can cause marked transaminitis and hyperbilirubinemia and could coexist with chronic HBV
Autoimmune hepatitis: can present with similar transaminase elevations and jaundice but serologies not yet assessed and HBV markers point to viral etiology.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Hepatitis B viral load (HBV DNA)

steps.new_information: Hepatitis B viral load (HBV DNA) returned with normal readings (no elevated HBV DNA detected).
current_uncertainties: Acute hepatitis B or acute-on-chronic HBV: HBsAg+, HBeAg+ and markedly elevated AST/ALT and bilirubin support active hepatitis, but normal HBV DNA makes active viral replication uncertain
Drug-induced liver injury (DILI): hepatocellular pattern (very high AST/ALT, normal ALP) and subacute onset could reflect a recent medication or supplement exposure
Autoimmune hepatitis: can present with markedly elevated transaminases and hyperbilirubinemia without elevated HBV DNA and would require serologic markers to confirm.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Hepatitis B core IgM antibody (anti-HBc IgM)

steps.new_information: Hepatitis B core IgM antibody (anti-HBc IgM) returned normal/negative.
current_uncertainties: Chronic hepatitis B with acute flare: HBsAg+, anti-HBc IgG+ and HBeAg+ with markedly elevated ALT/AST and bilirubin suggest flare
Acute primary hepatitis B: possible but anti-HBc IgM negative argues against acute primary infection
Drug-induced liver injury (DILI): can present with marked transaminase elevation and cholestasis—need medication/herbal/alcohol history
Autoimmune hepatitis: can present with high transaminases and hyperbilirubinemia—requires autoimmune serologies to evaluate.
steps.next_step_action: ASK PATIENT: Have you taken any new prescription medications, over-the-counter drugs, or herbal supplements recently, and do you drink alcohol (how much and how often)?

steps.new_information: Patient reports no new prescription, OTC, or herbal meds (only on glyburide, sitagliptin, multivitamin). Drinks alcohol 1–2 beers most evenings.
current_uncertainties: Chronic hepatitis B with acute biochemical flare: HBsAg+, anti-HBc IgG+, HBeAg+ with very high ALT/AST and elevated direct bilirubin suggests HBV-related active hepatitis though HBV DNA/IgM were reported normal
Drug-induced liver injury (glyburide or sitagliptin): patient on these agents which can rarely cause hepatocellular injury
Alcohol-associated hepatitis: daily alcohol use could contribute but AST:ALT ratio <1 and very high ALT make classic alcoholic hepatitis less likely
Autoimmune hepatitis: can present with markedly elevated transaminases and cholestatic features, needs serologic testing to exclude.
steps.next_step_action: ASK PATIENT: Have you ever been told you have hepatitis B or had abnormal liver tests in the past (any prior diagnosis of chronic liver disease)?

steps.new_information: Patient reports never having been told they have hepatitis B or abnormal liver tests previously; only diagnosed with diabetes.
current_uncertainties: Chronic hepatitis B with acute flare: HBsAg+, anti-HBc IgG+, HBeAg+ with hepatocellular pattern (very high AST/ALT) and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia suggests an HBV flare
HBV DNA result reported as 'NORMAL READINGS' creating uncertainty about viral replication level

Drug-induced liver injury (acetaminophen or other OTC/herbal): markedly elevated transaminases can be due to DILI despite patient denying new prescription meds—need explicit acetaminophen/OTC use history
Acute non-hepatitis B viral hepatitis (e.g., EBV/CMV): fever, systemic symptoms and high transaminases could be viral—HBV serologies may represent chronic carriage incidental to current process
Alcoholic hepatitis: patient drinks 1–2 beers nightly which is modest but chronic alcohol use can contribute—lab pattern (ALT>AST) makes this less likely but not excluded.
steps.next_step_action: ASK PATIENT: In the past 1–2 months have you taken acetaminophen (paracetamol), high doses of any over-the-counter pain relievers, herbal supplements, or recreational drugs — please list names, doses, and timing? Also, have you had any recent new sexual partners, tattoos, body piercings, or history of IV drug use or blood transfusions?

steps.new_information: Patient reports no acetaminophen or other OTC pain relievers, herbal supplements, or recreational drugs in past 1–2 months; no new sexual partners, tattoos, piercings, IV drug use, or blood transfusions (only routine meds and occasional alcohol 1–2 beers nightly).
current_uncertainties: Acute flare/reactivation of chronic hepatitis B: HBsAg+, HBeAg+ with markedly elevated ALT/AST and direct hyperbilirubinemia suggest active hepatitis though HBV DNA and anti-HBc IgM were reported normal
Hepatitis D (HDV) superinfection: severe hepatitis in an HBsAg+ patient is suspicious for HDV co- or superinfection which can cause high transaminases and severe disease
Other acute viral hepatitis (CMV/EBV/HSV): can cause very high transaminases and systemic symptoms despite negative HAV (immune) and HCV tests
Drug or alcohol-induced liver injury: patient drinks 1–2 beers nightly and is on oral diabetes meds—less likely given history but still possible.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Hepatitis D serology (anti-HDV IgM/IgG) and HDV RNA

steps.new_information: Hepatitis D serology (anti-HDV IgM/IgG) and HDV RNA returned normal (negative).
current_uncertainties: Acute-on-chronic hepatitis B (reactivation): HBsAg+, anti-HBc IgG+, HBeAg+ with markedly elevated AST/ALT and bilirubin suggests an active HBV flare though HBV DNA was reported normal
consider lab/viral dynamics or pre-core mutant
Autoimmune hepatitis: severe transaminase elevation and cholestatic hyperbilirubinemia possible without HBV DNA detection, unexplored autoimmune markers
Drug-induced liver injury (glyburide/sitagliptin or other OTC): timing less suggestive but possible cause of hepatocellular injury
Acute hepatitis B infection: less likely because anti-HBc IgM was normal, but cannot be fully excluded if serologies are atypical or early window period.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: INR, serum albumin, and repeat quantitative Hepatitis B viral load (HBV DNA PCR)

steps.new_information: INR and serum albumin are within normal limits; repeat quantitative HBV DNA is undetectable/normal.
current_uncertainties: Chronic hepatitis B with acute flare: HBsAg+, anti-HBc IgG+, HBeAg+ and marked hepatocellular injury (very high AST/ALT) and jaundice are consistent with an HBV flare, but undetectable HBV DNA is discordant
Acute non-hepatitis-B viral hepatitis (e.g., hepatitis E, CMV, EBV): can produce similar hepatocellular injury and would not be detected by the tested serologies

Drug-induced liver injury (including rare sulfonylurea hepatotoxicity or alcohol-related injury): patient denies new drugs but is on glyburide and drinks alcohol nightly — could explain hepatocellular pattern
Obstructive biliary pathology (choledocholithiasis, mass): direct hyperbilirubinemia and RUQ pain raise concern though alkaline phosphatase is normal and no Murphy sign.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Right upper quadrant abdominal ultrasound with Doppler

steps.new_information: Right upper quadrant abdominal ultrasound with Doppler reported normal (no biliary obstruction, no liver masses, normal hepatic vasculature).
current_uncertainties: Chronic hepatitis B with acute exacerbation/reactivation: HBsAg+, HBeAg+ and markedly elevated AST/ALT suggest active HBV-mediated injury, but repeatedly normal HBV DNA and anti-HBc IgM make acute/active replication uncertain
Autoimmune hepatitis: marked hepatocellular injury with direct hyperbilirubinemia and normal imaging could reflect autoimmune process
Drug-induced liver injury (e.g., glyburide or sitagliptin): temporal relationship lacking but DILI can present with hepatocellular pattern
Less likely obstructive biliary disease or hepatic vascular cause given normal ultrasound and Doppler.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Autoimmune hepatitis panel (ANA, ASMA, anti-LKM1) and total serum IgG level

steps.new_information: Autoimmune hepatitis panel (ANA, ASMA, anti-LKM1) and total serum IgG are within normal limits.
current_uncertainties: Acute hepatitis E: compatible with acute severe transaminase elevation, direct hyperbilirubinemia, RUQ pain and dark urine
Drug-induced liver injury (DILI) from sitagliptin or glyburide: possible idiosyncratic hepatotoxicity despite no new meds, explains high ALT/AST
Chronic hepatitis B with acute flare/reactivation: HBsAg+, HBeAg+ suggests HBV infection but HBV DNA and anti-HBc IgM are negative — inconsistent but possible low-level or occult reactivation
Autoimmune hepatitis: less likely given normal autoimmune serologies and IgG but cannot be 100% excluded.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Hepatitis E serology (HEV IgM and HEV RNA)

steps.new_information: Hepatitis E serology (HEV IgM and HEV RNA) returned negative (normal readings).
current_uncertainties: Immune-active chronic hepatitis B flare: HBsAg+, anti-HBc IgG+, HBeAg+ with markedly elevated ALT/AST and bilirubin suggests an HBV-related hepatic flare though HBV DNA is currently undetectable (immune clearance may suppress viremia)
Acute hepatitis B infection: HBsAg+ and HBeAg+ with high transaminases fits acute HBV, but anti-HBc IgM is negative arguing against acute primary infection

Drug-induced liver injury (DILI) from glyburide (sulfonylurea) or sitagliptin: can produce hepatocellular injury with high ALT/AST and would explain negative viral loads/serologies for acute infection
Autoimmune hepatitis (seronegative): high transaminases and hyperbilirubinemia can be autoimmune despite negative ANA/ASMA/IgG in some cases.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Repeat sensitive quantitative HBV DNA PCR (lower limit of detection ≤10 IU/mL) and quantitative HBsAg and HBeAg levels

steps.new_information: Repeat sensitive quantitative HBV DNA PCR (lower limit ≤10 IU/mL) and quantitative HBsAg and HBeAg levels returned within normal/readings.
current_uncertainties: Chronic hepatitis B with immune-active flare: HBsAg/HBeAg positivity and markedly elevated ALT/AST and bilirubin suggest HBV-related injury, but repeatedly normal HBV DNA and now quantitative HBsAg/HBeAg conflict with prior serology
Acute hepatitis B infection: high transaminases and jaundice possible but anti-HBc IgM is negative and prior HBsAg unknown—serology timelines unclear
Drug-induced liver injury (DILI): patient on glyburide/sitagliptin and reports alcohol use, DILI can cause marked transaminase elevations and cholestasis despite negative viral testing
Other viral hepatitis/viral hepatitis mimic (HSV, CMV, EBV): can cause severe transaminitis and hyperbilirubinemia despite negative HBV DNA.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: HBV DNA PCR at an independent/reference laboratory (ultra-sensitive) and HBV genome sequencing (pre-core/core promoter and S gene) to evaluate for assay interference or mutant virus

steps.new_information: Ultra-sensitive HBV DNA PCR at reference lab and HBV genome sequencing returned negative/normal (no detectable HBV DNA or mutant S/pre-core/core-promoter variants).
current_uncertainties: Acute non-HBV viral hepatitis (HSV/CMV/EBV): marked hepatocellular injury with very high ALT/AST and negative HBV DNA suggests another viral cause
Drug-induced liver injury (glyburide or sitagliptin): compatible with hepatocellular pattern and patient on chronic meds but no new drugs

Chronic HBV with HBsAg production from integrated HBV DNA plus separate acute hepatic injury: explains persistent HBsAg/HBeAg positivity with absent viremia, but doesn't by itself explain acute transaminitis
Autoimmune or seronegative autoimmune hepatitis: LFT pattern fits but autoimmune panel normal, still possible.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: HSV PCR, CMV PCR, and EBV VCA IgM/IgG

steps.new_information: HSV PCR, CMV PCR, and EBV VCA IgM/IgG returned negative (normal readings).
current_uncertainties: Acute hepatitis B infection: initial serology showed HBsAg+, HBeAg+ but HBV DNA repeatedly undetectable and anti-HBc IgM negative, creating discordance
still possible early acute or atypical serologic pattern

Drug-induced liver injury (glyburide or sitagliptin) or alcohol-related hepatitis: patient uses daily alcohol and is on medications known rarely to cause hepatotoxicity—fits hepatocellular injury with markedly elevated AST/ALT
Occult/other viral hepatitis (window period HCV or false-negative HCV Ab): anti-HCV negative but RNA not performed—acute HCV possible though less likely
Wilson disease or metabolic liver disease: unexplained high transaminases with anemia and hepatomegaly—consider if patient is young or has hemolysis.
steps.next_step_action: ASK PATIENT: How old are you?

steps.new_information: Final diagnosis reached: Drug-induced liver injury
steps.next_step_action: DIAGNOSIS READY
steps.reason_ready: Extensive infectious (HAV, HCV, HDV, HEV, HSV, CMV, EBV) and autoimmune testing were repeatedly negative, abdominal imaging was normal, and sensitive HBV DNA testing (including sequencing and independent labs) failed to confirm active HBV replication despite HBsAg/HBeAg positivity — suggesting the HBsAg/HBeAg results are likely assay interference or nonreplicative. The clinical picture (3 weeks of RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, dark urine, markedly elevated ALT/AST with normal ALP) is most consistent with an acute hepatocellular injury from drug-induced liver injury (most likely related to the patient’s oral hypoglycemic agents) after other causes were effectively excluded.
steps.synthesis_prompt:
You are a medical diagnosis synthesizer. Based on all the information gathered during a clinical evaluation, provide a single, specific final diagnosis.

## Information Gathered:
- Patient presents with generalized fatigue, mild fever, abdominal pain, and nausea.
- Vital signs: Temperature 38.1°C, Blood Pressure 110/74 mm Hg, Heart Rate 99/min, Respiratory Rate normal.
- Patient reports pain localized to right upper abdomen under the ribs (RUQ) that began ~3 weeks ago and started along with fatigue and nausea.
- Liver enlarged 2–3 cm below right costal margin (hepatomegaly) with RUQ tenderness; no Murphy sign, no guarding or rebound; normal inspection and auscultation.
- Patient reports dark (tea-colored) urine; no scleral or skin jaundice; normal-colored stools.
- Marked transaminitis (AST 488 U/L, ALT 798 U/L) with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (total bilirubin 3.6 mg/dL, direct 2.4 mg/dL), hepatomegaly and RUQ tenderness; CBC shows mild anemia (Hb 10.6 g/dL) and leukocytosis (11,600/mm3); Hepatitis serologies: Hep A IgG positive, HBsAg positive, anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg positive, Hep C antibody negative.
- Hepatitis B viral load (HBV DNA) returned with normal readings (no elevated HBV DNA detected).
- Hepatitis B core IgM antibody (anti-HBc IgM) returned normal/negative.
- Patient reports no new prescription, OTC, or herbal meds (only on glyburide, sitagliptin, multivitamin). Drinks alcohol 1–2 beers most evenings.
- Patient reports never having been told they have hepatitis B or abnormal liver tests previously; only diagnosed with diabetes.
- Patient reports no acetaminophen or other OTC pain relievers, herbal supplements, or recreational drugs in past 1–2 months; no new sexual partners, tattoos, piercings, IV drug use, or blood transfusions (only routine meds and occasional alcohol 1–2 beers nightly).
- Hepatitis D serology (anti-HDV IgM/IgG) and HDV RNA returned normal (negative).
- INR and serum albumin are within normal limits; repeat quantitative HBV DNA is undetectable/normal.
- Right upper quadrant abdominal ultrasound with Doppler reported normal (no biliary obstruction, no liver masses, normal hepatic vasculature).
- Autoimmune hepatitis panel (ANA, ASMA, anti-LKM1) and total serum IgG are within normal limits.
- Hepatitis E serology (HEV IgM and HEV RNA) returned negative (normal readings).
- Repeat sensitive quantitative HBV DNA PCR (lower limit ≤10 IU/mL) and quantitative HBsAg and HBeAg levels returned within normal/readings.
- Ultra-sensitive HBV DNA PCR at reference lab and HBV genome sequencing returned negative/normal (no detectable HBV DNA or mutant S/pre-core/core-promoter variants).
- HSV PCR, CMV PCR, and EBV VCA IgM/IgG returned negative (normal readings).

## Task:
Provide a single, specific diagnosis (1-3 words). Examples:
- "Acute appendicitis"
- "Community-acquired pneumonia"
- "Type 2 diabetes mellitus"

Diagnosis:

Differential: Acute hepatitis E: compatible with acute severe transaminase elevation, direct hyperbilirubinemia, RUQ pain and dark urine, Drug-induced liver injury (DILI) from sitagliptin or glyburide: possible idiosyncratic hepatotoxicity despite no new meds, explains high ALT/AST, Chronic hepatitis B with acute flare/reactivation: HBsAg+, HBeAg+ suggests HBV infection but HBV DNA and anti-HBc IgM are negative — inconsistent but possible low-level or occult reactivation, Autoimmune hepatitis: less likely given normal autoimmune serologies and IgG but cannot be 100% excluded.
Next: REQUEST TEST: Hepatitis E serology (HEV IgM and HEV RNA)

[Step 16]
New Info: Hepatitis E serology (HEV IgM and HEV RNA) returned negative (normal readings).
Differential: Immune-active chronic hepatitis B flare: HBsAg+, anti-HBc IgG+, HBeAg+ with markedly elevated ALT/AST and bilirubin suggests an HBV-related hepatic flare though HBV DNA is currently undetectable (immune clearance may suppress viremia), Acute hepatitis B infection: HBsAg+ and HBeAg+ with high transaminases fits acute HBV, but anti-HBc IgM is negative arguing against acute primary infection, Drug-induced liver injury (DILI) from glyburide (sulfonylurea) or sitagliptin: can produce hepatocellular injury with high ALT/AST and would explain negative viral loads/serologies for acute infection, Autoimmune hepatitis (seronegative): high transaminases and hyperbilirubinemia can be autoimmune despite negative ANA/ASMA/IgG in some cases.
Next: REQUEST TEST: Repeat sensitive quantitative HBV DNA PCR (lower limit of detection ≤10 IU/mL) and quantitative HBsAg and HBeAg levels

[Step 17]
New Info: Repeat sensitive quantitative HBV DNA PCR (lower limit ≤10 IU/mL) and quantitative HBsAg and HBeAg levels returned within normal/readings.
Differential: Chronic hepatitis B with immune-active flare: HBsAg/HBeAg positivity and markedly elevated ALT/AST and bilirubin suggest HBV-related injury, but repeatedly normal HBV DNA and now quantitative HBsAg/HBeAg conflict with prior serology, Acute hepatitis B infection: high transaminases and jaundice possible but anti-HBc IgM is negative and prior HBsAg unknown—serology timelines unclear, Drug-induced liver injury (DILI): patient on glyburide/sitagliptin and reports alcohol use, DILI can cause marked transaminase elevations and cholestasis despite negative viral testing, Other viral hepatitis/viral hepatitis mimic (HSV, CMV, EBV): can cause severe transaminitis and hyperbilirubinemia despite negative HBV DNA.
Next: REQUEST TEST: HBV DNA PCR at an independent/reference laboratory (ultra-sensitive) and HBV genome sequencing (pre-core/core promoter and S gene) to evaluate for assay interference or mutant virus

[Step 18]
New Info: Ultra-sensitive HBV DNA PCR at reference lab and HBV genome sequencing returned negative/normal (no detectable HBV DNA or mutant S/pre-core/core-promoter variants).
Differential: Acute non-HBV viral hepatitis (HSV/CMV/EBV): marked hepatocellular injury with very high ALT/AST and negative HBV DNA suggests another viral cause, Drug-induced liver injury (glyburide or sitagliptin): compatible with hepatocellular pattern and patient on chronic meds but no new drugs, Chronic HBV with HBsAg production from integrated HBV DNA plus separate acute hepatic injury: explains persistent HBsAg/HBeAg positivity with absent viremia, but doesn't by itself explain acute transaminitis, Autoimmune or seronegative autoimmune hepatitis: LFT pattern fits but autoimmune panel normal, still possible.
Next: REQUEST TEST: HSV PCR, CMV PCR, and EBV VCA IgM/IgG

[Step 19]
New Info: HSV PCR, CMV PCR, and EBV VCA IgM/IgG returned negative (normal readings).
Differential: Acute hepatitis B infection: initial serology showed HBsAg+, HBeAg+ but HBV DNA repeatedly undetectable and anti-HBc IgM negative, creating discordance, still possible early acute or atypical serologic pattern, Drug-induced liver injury (glyburide or sitagliptin) or alcohol-related hepatitis: patient uses daily alcohol and is on medications known rarely to cause hepatotoxicity—fits hepatocellular injury with markedly elevated AST/ALT, Occult/other viral hepatitis (window period HCV or false-negative HCV Ab): anti-HCV negative but RNA not performed—acute HCV possible though less likely, Wilson disease or metabolic liver disease: unexplained high transaminases with anemia and hepatomegaly—consider if patient is young or has hemolysis.
Next: ASK PATIENT: How old are you?
